Major-projects.name: Positive Note Android
Major-projects.desc: This was the first major app I wrote in Android. In the class that first taught me Android development, we were asked to create an app that would help those in their day-to-day lives whether that was an acessibility issue, a handicap, or simply a health-related concern. Being a Biology major focused in Neuroscience, I immediately thought about the issue of mental illness. I hoped to create an app that would help users to be able to voice their concerns about their mental well-being if they felt they could not do so easily. Ideally I could create a chat system, map out local mental health professionals, display helpful articles and create a simple login. The biggest concern, and ultimately the task I could not complete, was the chat system. I had hoped to create a system that would connect users who felt they could help in certain topics whether relationships, depression, or simply daily troubles with users who were having trouble in these topics. Though the system was established programmatically with help from Firebase (just before Google acquired it), it didn't function as intended. Consequently, the remainder was fleshed out as best as possible within the time frame, and the chat system was kept basic. Despite my shortcomings, it taught me a number of important lessons from project management, laying out tasks, and interacting with a number of different technologies.

Major-projects.name: Infection Control Android
Major-projects.desc: This app started in Android before moving more recently into iOS. Originally an idea of my father's, I began this app to help solve an issue of data collection and data visualization for his department, Infection Control, at work. However, as I worked out the details with him, it became more apparent how helpful this app could be for not only his own hospital but for hospitals in general. In his experience, hospitals often lag behind in terms of technology, despite being able to benefit immensely from the revolution data collection and computeres can bring.  Ideally as I further pursue this project to its limits, I can generalize and help a number of different hospitals, beginning with local clinics, offering a cheap and user friendly experience to help those in need. Beginning with the Android app, I wanted a simple user interface that would quickly and immediately enable users to create reports when needed. In addition, I wanted to ensure that administrative users had the tools to cater to their clinics needs, adapting the base app as necessary. While the settings portion of the app is still a work in progress, the biggest challenges came from filtering reports and implementing nested Recycler Views. Both will be improved upon to some degree, but getting them done as neatly as possible was a huge point of pride and an important set of lessons in routine Android app development. In the future, I'll add graphs and improved filtering as with the Android app. In addition to this, I expect to improve the settings to allow administrative staff control, look, feel and data collectable.

Small-projects.name: A Few of My Favorite Foods from Around the World
Small-projects.desc: I found that as I developed these Android apps, the entire operating system felt very intuitive and just as customizable as a developer as it is for a user. Naturally it was important for our teacher to remind us that it's not always necessary to re-invent the wheel, so we took a look at a very commonly used 3rd party dependency, Glide. Using Glide we could load in images to the image view based on URL, and create that much more intuitive and creative apps. With this simple example, every flag was clickable, and when clicked, the URL would change, revealing a different food item that the student enjoyed .

Small-projects.name: Try and Escape!
Small-projects.desc: After several basic attempts, it was finally time to learn something a bit more complicated and specific to how the Android OS works, fragments. Using fragments, the goal was to use a single activity to contain all the screens of the App, being sure they all interacted with each other as necessary. In the end, I created an escape room type game with several 'rooms', each with a different puzzle to solve, that the user needs to complete to beat the entire game.

Small-projects.name: Keep a Notebook
Small-projects.desc: After using understanding spinners, the natural progression in Android was to start using List views for a more complex layout. Implementing adapters to feed the list view data was a bit more of a challenge but understanding it helped immensely when recycler views became more common and important in the Android UI ecosystem. Finally after making iOS apps for some time and learning a number of daily-use aspects of Android, my Android apps were starting to feel fully fledged and I was ready for my big semester project after completing a project that would feature some of the most common features of apps, a simple list, saving data and persisting it.

Small-projects.name: Enter the Hazard Room
Small-projects.desc: As I worked on my final project, Positive Note, my class continued to improve upon basic skills, teaching me a new skill that I hadn't learned much from my iOS development, database interactions. It's this app experience that encouraged me to use Firebase for maintaining messaging and user data. Overall as frustrating as finishing a text based game in Android was, it was an extremely worthwhile experience and one that I still reference for a deeper and more base level understanding of Android's cursor handling of databases. This knowledge certainly serves one well for implementing CLEAN architecture and Android's Room Persistance library.
